headline.main: YALE COLLEGE.; The Literary Societies The Prize Debates The University Quarterly The War Spirit Wooden Spoon Presentation Day.

docs.lead_paragraph: YALE COLLEGE, Wednesday, June 19, 1861. The Summer Term at Yale College, is the most marked of the year. It is enlivened by two Biennials, Commencement, a boating furor, and a train of college customs, increasing in expense to the students every year.

docs.snippet: The Royal Mail steamship Africa, Capt. SHANNON, which left Liverpool at 10 A.M. on the 8th, and Queestown on the evening of the 9th inst., arrived here yesterday morning. She brings $368,000 in specie.

headline.main: THREE DAYS LATER FROM EUROPE.; ARRIVAL OF THE AFRICA. $368,000 IN SPECIE. headline.main: THE LONDON TIMES CORRESPONDENCE.; Letters from Mr. William Russell on his Travels through the South.

docs.snippet: A regiment has been ordered from here to Columbus, Ky., to protect the Union men there from the depredations of the Secessionists. The Unionists had applied to Gen. PRENTISS, at Cairo, for protection.
docs.lead_paragraph: A regiment has been ordered from here to Columbus, Ky., to protect the Union men there from the depredations of the Secessionists. The Unionists had applied to Gen. PRENTISS, at Cairo, for protection.

headline.main: NEWS OF THE REBELLION.; [The following dispatches appeared in a portion of our Morning Edition yesterday.] SPECIAL DISPATCH FROM WASHINGTON. MORE TROOPS FROM THE WEST. COL. SMALL'S REGIMENT. BALLOON TELEGRAPHING. THE HIGHLAND GUARD BANQUET.

docs.lead_paragraph: The rebel soldiers at Manassas Junction complain bitterly of being compelled to dig and delve in the ditches, during the excessive heat, while the negroes who have been pressed into the service are lazy worthless for the purposes to which they have been for a time assigned.

docs.snippet: A regiment has been ordered from here to Columbus, Ky., to protect the Union men there from the depredatious of the Secessionists. The Unionists had applied to Gen. PRENTISS, at Cairo, for protection.

headline.main: THE BLOCKADING SERVICE.; LETTER FROM ON BOARD THE POWHATAN. Correspondence of the New-York Times.

docs.snippet: On the occasion of the departure of the Fourteenth Illinois Regiment from Jacksonville, a few days since, a banquet was given by the citizens. Gov. Yates was invited to attend, but wrote a letter, by way of apology, in which he said:
docs.lead_paragraph: On the occasion of the departure of the Fourteenth Illinois Regiment from Jacksonville, a few days since, a banquet was given by the citizens. Gov. Yates was invited to attend, but wrote a letter, by way of apology, in which he said:

docs.snippet: The ship Monarch of the Sea, Capt. GARDNER, arrived at this port yesterday from Liverpool, having a general cargo and 954 Mormon passengers. This is the largest number of Mormons that ever arrived at this port in one vessel.
docs.lead_paragraph: The ship Monarch of the Sea, Capt. GARDNER, arrived at this port yesterday from Liverpool, having a general cargo and 954 Mormon passengers. This is the largest number of Mormons that ever arrived at this port in one vessel.

headline.main: THE BLOCKADING SERCIVE.; LETTER FROM ON BOARD THE POWHATAN.

docs.lead_paragraph: The chance to send a letter to the TIMES has offered, and I cheerfully embrace it. My long silence was occasioned by two facts: First, we left Pickens. Second, although in Mobile, I dared not send a note to one whom I knew would gladly dispatch a letter for me, because it would be unwise in me to do so.
